stream_context.summary: Kaze debugs a persistent crash in a Course 13 area (eventually traced to a specific coin formation/actor), discusses emulator support strategy (Project64 + GlideN64 vs Parallel), and begins planning/building the final “retro section” concept for Course 13—settling on a black-and-white Super Mario Land 1 inspired forced-perspective plane/shooter corridor with a fixed camera and 60 FPS target. He also mentions recent off-stream UV mapping work and personal context (parents visiting, new motivation to stream daily for efficiency/income).
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a concrete technical debugging arc (crash cause identified) and a firm creative decision for a major retro segment (Super Mario Land 1 plane section with specific gameplay/camera constraints), plus clear statements about emulator support and production constraints.

findings.summary: A recurring crash in the level was caused by a specific coin formation (an actor) rather than collision; removing the problematic formation stopped the crash and let Kaze continue work.

Kaze uses Project64 for day-to-day development because it boots quickly and he has established workarounds for its bugs; he explicitly does not want to support multiple emulators because each requires separate bug workarounds.
findings.quote: Every emulator is broken as fuck… I just have to pick one emulator and run with it.

findings.summary: For this hack’s rendering path, Kaze expects Project64 running with GlideN64 to be the practical/primary emulator setup; he considers Parallel unreliable and effectively unsupported for this project.
findings.quote: Parallel will literally never work. It is forever doomed.

findings.summary: Kaze encountered pipeline/tooling friction around the Fast64 “upgrader” and UI/readme expectations; after guidance from Lilaa, he found an “install main” update path in preferences that resolved the confusion.
Course 13 is nearing its planned endgame structure: Kaze states the “Space Arcade” and “Papercraft” are the last two major parts, and he is now building the “retro section” within Course 13.
findings.quote: We’re in course 13… the Space Arcade and the Papercraft level are the last two.

findings.summary: Kaze sets a firm rule for retro references: only games released before Mario 64 are eligible, to preserve a period-authentic feel for the hack’s retro inclusions.
findings.quote: Only games that released before Mario 64 are eligible.

findings.summary: For the next retro segment, Kaze makes Super Mario Land 1 non-negotiable (partly due to personal nostalgia), rejecting substituting other retro games unless SML1 is moved later.

He explores multiple SML1 candidates (submarine vs space/plane), but rejects submarine/vehicle ideas due to difficulty making them interesting and because they would require many front-facing sprites—beyond scope/budget.
findings.quote: I don’t want to make front sprites for everything… Budget cuts.

findings.summary: Kaze pivots toward an SML1 plane section that borrows the feel of a rail shooter (Star Fox-like), using a forced-perspective fixed camera where the player moves in screen space and shoots with A.
findings.quote: The camera will be permanently stuck like this… you’re allowed to move in screen space… pressing A to shoot.

findings.summary: He decides to represent the plane/enemies with simple 3D models (and possibly voxel/sprite-like animation) to avoid needing many bespoke front sprites, while still matching the black-and-white aesthetic.
The engine does not support an “area background” for a solid white void; instead, Kaze chooses a corridor approach (walls/rims) to visually constrain the play area and avoid new engine work.
findings.quote: Area background is not supported in this engine.

findings.summary: Black-and-white presentation is treated as essential to the SML1 homage; he considers fog to prevent the corridor from looking bad when the player can see too far, balancing aesthetic vs readability.
findings.quote: Now we’re definitely doing the whole thing in black and white. That’s essential to the aesthetic.

findings.summary: Kaze notes he did off-stream basic UV mapping (including walls) and is now focused on getting wall UVs ‘half decent’ before moving fully into the retro section buildout.

He explains he plans to stream nearly every day because he is efficient working on-stream and wants to increase income; he references having taken time off related to having a child and needing to work more afterward.
findings.quote: I’m gonna just stream like basically every day now. Because I’m very efficient working on stream.

findings.summary: Parents are visiting in Germany (10-day stay), creating extra real-life workload (garden/automatic lawnmower setup) and also bringing a large number of Yoshi plushies—reinforcing the project’s Yoshi identity in his home life.
findings.quote: They brought like 15 Yoshis. I have so many Yoshi plushies now.

biobak.summary: Biobak is consulted/implicitly asked to validate the choice of Super Mario Land 1 as the retro inspiration, indicating Kaze uses Biobak as a sounding board for creative direction.

findings.summary: Lilaa guides Kaze through updating/installing the correct ‘main’ branch/version of the Fast64 upgrader via Preferences → 64 → ‘Check for update and install main,’ resolving a tooling blocker.
Lilaa also appears involved in repository/settings workflow issues (layer naming/enum mapping), prompting Kaze to re-check repo settings and layer conventions.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Every emulator is broken as fuck… I just have to pick one emulator and run with it.
memorable_quotes.context: Explaining why he standardizes development/testing around a single emulator workflow rather than supporting multiple emulator-specific bugs.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.context: A firm creative boundary-setting moment about which retro game must be represented, tied to nostalgia and completeness of the retro lineup.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Area background is not supported in this engine.
memorable_quotes.context: A concise constraint statement that shapes how the SML1 plane segment will be constructed (corridor/rims instead of a simple white void).

key_stories.title: Course 13 crash traced to a coin formation actor
key_stories.summary: Kaze investigates a persistent crash and initially suspects collision complexity. After narrowing it down, he identifies that one of the coin formations (an actor placement) is responsible and removing it stops the crash.
key_stories.challenge: The level repeatedly crashed, blocking progress and making it unclear whether collision, memory, or actor logic was to blame.
key_stories.process: He tests hypotheses (collision triangle count, actor suspicion), removes multiple coin formations, and cross-references actor IDs/placements until he finds the specific formation causing the crash.
key_stories.outcome: The crash is resolved by removing the problematic coin formation, allowing him to continue with UV work and the retro section.

key_stories.title: Choosing a Super Mario Land 1 retro section under strict constraints
key_stories.summary: Kaze decides the next retro homage must be Super Mario Land 1 and iterates through candidate level concepts (submarine/vehicle vs plane). He rejects options that would demand extensive front-facing sprite work or feel like a worse copy of the original game.
key_stories.challenge: Make an SML1-inspired segment that feels fresh in Mario 64 while staying within production limits and matching the hack’s retro philosophy.
key_stories.process: He sets rules (pre-Mario-64 releases only; black-and-white aesthetic), evaluates submarine/vehicle ideas, then pivots to a forced-perspective plane/shooter corridor with screen-space movement and shooting.
key_stories.outcome: A clear direction emerges: a rail-shooter-like plane segment with a fixed camera, 3D models for enemies, corridor rims to bound play space, and likely fog for presentation.
key_stories.key_quote: The camera will be permanently stuck like this… you’re allowed to move in screen space… pressing A to shoot.

key_stories.title: Tooling friction: Fast64 upgrader/update path confusion
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggles with an ‘upgrader’ workflow (missing readme, UI confusion) and worries the process is unclear for everyone if he can’t figure it out. With Lilaa’s steps, he finds the correct update/install route.
key_stories.challenge: Blocked by unclear/incorrect tooling update procedure and UI expectations.
key_stories.process: He searches for documentation, checks preferences/settings, and follows Lilaa’s exact menu path to ‘install main.’
key_stories.outcome: The upgrader/update process is clarified enough to proceed, and he considers requesting UI improvements so others don’t repeat the confusion.

open_questions.context: Kaze confirms a specific coin formation actor caused the crash, but the underlying technical reason (data corruption, bad parameters, engine regression, exporter bug, or memory issue) is not explained.
questions: What exactly about that coin formation made it crash (specific behavior script, malformed data, invalid pointer/geo layout, object list overflow, etc.)?
Was this introduced by the new exporter/upgrader/F3DEX3 pipeline, or is it a longstanding SM64 engine edge case?
What safeguards/tools could prevent similar actor-placement crashes (validation, linting, runtime assertions)?

open_questions.topic: Emulator support and ‘only way to play’ claim
open_questions.context: Kaze strongly favors Project64 + GlideN64 and dismisses Parallel; he implies GlideN64 updated for X3 will be effectively required.
questions: What specific graphics/engine features (X3/F3DEX3 path, custom rendering, materials) break on other emulators?
Is real hardware the primary target, and how does emulator compatibility factor into release planning and QA?
Will the team publish an ‘official’ recommended emulator/version/configuration for players?

open_questions.topic: Course 13 structure: Space Arcade + Papercraft + Retro section integration
open_questions.context: Kaze states Space Arcade and Papercraft are the last two big pieces in Course 13 and begins designing the SML1 retro segment inside it.
questions: How do Space Arcade, Papercraft, and the SML1 retro segment connect narratively and mechanically within Course 13?
What is the player’s pacing through these sections (checkpointing, star/mission structure, difficulty ramp)?
What remains unfinished in Course 13 after this stream?

open_questions.context: Kaze enforces a rule that retro references must be from games released before Mario 64 to preserve a period feel.
questions: When did this ‘pre-Mario-64 only’ rule become a guiding principle, and why?
Are there exceptions (regional release dates, hardware constraints, or ‘spirit of the era’ arguments)?
How do you balance authenticity vs player recognition and variety?

open_questions.context: Kaze outlines a fixed-camera, screen-space movement, A-to-shoot design with corridor bounds; targets 60 FPS.
questions: What engine changes (if any) are needed for this gameplay (camera locking, input mapping, projectile/enemy patterns)?
How will collision and depth be handled in forced perspective (true 3D vs constrained 2D plane)?
What defines success/failure states and objectives in this segment (time, rings/coins, boss, score)?

open_questions.context: Kaze says black-and-white is essential and discusses fog/visibility; he also notes textures/materials look different due to ‘upgraded materials.’
questions: How do you technically enforce the black-and-white look (palette, texture pass, post-processing, lighting rules)?
What were the ‘upgraded materials’ changes, and how did they affect texture appearance/performance?
How do you keep readability/contrast while staying faithful to SML1’s look?

open_questions.context: Kaze avoids adding area background support and instead builds a corridor to bound the play space.
questions: Why isn’t area background supported (technical debt, renderer architecture, memory/perf constraints)?
Was adding it considered earlier, and what would it have cost?
Are there other engine constraints shaping level design in similar ways across the project?

open_questions.topic: Fast64 upgrader/UI PR and pipeline ownership
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions being in a PR for upgraded changes and wanting UI updates so people upgrade correctly; Lilaa provides steps to install ‘main.’
questions: What changes were in the PR (F3DEX3 preview, exporter behavior, UI fixes), and who authored them?
What broke in Kaze’s workflow, and how common is this issue for other creators?
What is the current recommended toolchain for contributors (Fast64 versioning, settings, validation steps)?

open_questions.topic: Work cadence shift: streaming daily for efficiency/income
open_questions.context: Kaze says he’ll stream basically every day to work efficiently and make more money; he references time off related to having a child.
questions: What changed financially or motivationally that prompted the ‘stream every day’ plan?
How does streaming affect productivity vs deep work off-stream?
How do family responsibilities (new child, visits) interact with production schedules?

open_questions.topic: Physics ‘raycast’ changes referenced but not explained
open_questions.context: A chat message notes that calling the changes ‘raycast physics’ undersells the power of the physics changes, but details aren’t explored.
questions: What were the physics changes, and what gameplay did they unlock (new movement, interactions, stability)?
Were these changes made for a specific level or system (vehicles, platforming, enemies)?
What were the hardest bugs or side effects of the new physics approach?
